Sail Away is played on a board resembling a nautical chart overlaid by a square grid. The game includes six metal yachts numbered 1 through 6. The yachts lean to one side or the other according to their tack. The yachts are moved across the map using the intersections of the grid lines.

Movement is governed by a spinner which has an inner and outer circle of results - one circle for the upwind leg, and the other circle for the downwind and crosswind legs. In addition to the bit of luck injected by the spinner (reflecting the vagaries of the wind), there is also a slight chance for misfortune - two small spaces on the spinner allow for a player to lose a turn for having a man overboard and two turns for capsizing. The rules also cover blanketing effects by windward yachts toward leeward yachts, tacking, and jibing.

The course is somewhat fixed in that the wind direction is always the same (southeast) and there are three course markers designated on the map. However, there are four different courses that may be run: counterclockwise around the triangular course described by the three markers, clockwise around the triangular course, around course marker 2 and back, or around course marker 3 and back. In addition, players may choose to race one lap or multiple laps.

7123.name: Airport
7123.description:
"Consider yourself the Captain of an airliner on a flight from Miami, Florida to Seattle, Washington. The object of the game is to pilot your aircraft along the airways, crossing over the cities of your choice, in route to the destination airport and be the first to complete the flight."

"This game is designed to be a realistic experience for the player, as many of the game rules are based on actual federal air regulations."

"Pilot-players pit themselves against each other and other flying odds as they strive to stay in the lead. Each pilot must be careful of thunderstorms which can unexpectedly cross their paths, just as in a real flight. Each pilot might also hit strong headwinds, severe icing or even clear air turbulence, as they fly across the country."

7124.name: Straightaway
7124.description: "A new look at the high-speed world of Grand Prix auto racing. Cars, drivers, the color and excitement of the race itself, with an important plus. Sponsorship of racing cars is big money business for the corporations and individuals who produce automotive parts and products. Now is your chance to be the heavy-spending sponsor of some of the world's fastest racing machinery. Through a new computer-type format you watch your drivers duel through lap after lap of flat out excitement, with your money riding on every down shift, power slide and switchback. An authentic and fascinating way of enjoying the thrills of official Grand Prix racing."

7125.name: Hornswoggle
7125.description:
"Your mission, should you choose to accept it, is to seek out your opponents and devastate them financially. You will assume the disguise of an attorney and the alias of your choice (Scooter Cohooter, Kid Fleece, L. Gotcha, or Sam Boozlebam). The rules and suggestions are only guidelines; you may operate on the principle that anything you can get away with is legal. In order to preserve the spirit of Hornswoggle, I recommend no mercy be extended to those players in dire financial straits."

Hornswoggle was designed to capture the essence and true spirit of the legal system. Certain modifications were necessary to make the game function logically (unlike the real thing)."

"Objective: To have the most money on deposit in the Swiss Bank after the game ends. You will accomplish this by suing your opponents. One third of your profits will be deposited in your Swiss Bank account."

7126.name: Silver Cup Sailboat Racing Game
7126.description: A simple sailboat racing game where the players race along a track around the board. Movement is governed by a spinner. Players may be confronted with trivia questions (regarding sailing) during the game - a correct answer moves a boat forward and an incorrect answer moves a boat backward. Additional cards are drawn during the game which provide further information regarding sailing.

7127.name: Windshifts
7127.description:
Dubbed "A Tactical Sailing Game", Windshifts uses a novel game system combined with unusual components to recreate international yacht racing.

The board is randomly created as the race develops using 19 plastic map cards that lock together. The race is in three segments; a windward leg, a downwind leg, and then another windward leg to the finish line. As portions of the race are completed, the map cards from that segment are returned to the draw pile to be reused later in the game.

There are no spaces on the board. The direction and strength of the wind are indicated by lines on the plastic map cards. The distance a ship moves is determined by the wind strength and the ship's bearing in relation to the wind direction.

The ships have clear plastic bases with a numbered wheel mounted in the center. The ships' bases have lines molded into them that are aligned with the lines on the map cards to establish the bearing of a ship. As the ship is moved across the map, the wheel in the center turns, and each number on the wheel indicates one unit of movement. On a map card with strong wind indicated a ship bearing on a beat, broad reach or downwind moves 4 units or one complete revolution of the wheel. A beam reach bearing generates 6 units of movement. On a map card with light wind indicated, the movements are half.

A plastic "windshadow" card is used to determine when an opposing boat is in "disturbed air" - this differs based on whether the boats are on the downwind or windward (upwind) leg. The sail of a ship will cause the air downwind (behind) of it to move in weak chaotic swirl patterns, the sail effectively blocks the wind from supplying power to any other boat following downwind within about 1 1/2 boat lengths. In the game, the "windshadow" card is used to determine if one boat has blocked the wind from powering another boat. If this is the case, the movement of the blocked boat is reduced.

7128.name: AirLand Battle: Corps Operational Command in Europe
7128.description:
AirLand Battle: Corps Operational Command in Europe is an operational level wargame that pits an American corps against a Soviet combined arms army which is reinforced by a second echelon tank army.

Players control additional air, artillery and helicopter assets.

This hex and counter wargame features limited intelligence, doctrinal tactical formations, organic supplies, missile and artillery ammunition restrictions, electronic warfare capabilities, chemical warfare, night combat restrictions, special light infantry capabilities, air interdiction and close air support units, refit of units and more.

7129.description:
Force Eagle's War, is the first game in the Tactical Combat Series (TCS) Modern Expansion. It features a hypothetical two day battle between Soviet and US heavy forces on the West Bank of Jordan in the mid-1990's.

Nine scenarios are provided including three time-warp scenarios which allow one to use modern forces against World War II forces found in the Bloody 110 game by The Gamers.

Game Scale:
Game Turn: 20 minutes
Hex: 125 yards / 114 meters
Units: Infantry platoons, individual vehicles

Game Inventory:
Two 22 x 34" full color maps
Two dual-side printed countersheets (840 1/2" counters)
One 32-page TCS-specific rulebook
One 8-page TCS Modern Expansion rulebook
One 16-page game specific rulebook
One 6-page TCS Charts, Tables, Errata folder
Two 6-sided dice
7129.name: Force Eagle's War

7130.description:
Battle Cry! is a man-to-man wargame covering infantry battles on a tactical level between US Marine units and the Imperial Japanese army units. The scale is 10 metres from hexside to hexside and each counter represents a single infantry.

Four maps are provided which simulates the typical terrain found in the Pacific War. The maps include a beach map, jungle map, mixed terrain map and rough terrain map.

Each individual unit will have a performance rating (PR) which requires that a performance check (PC) be made before moving, firing, observing or assaulting.

The advanced game includes armoured fighting vehicles (AFVs), crew-served weapons, anti-tank weapons, mortars, flamethrowers, mines, hidden units and more.
7130.name: Battle Cry!

7131.description:
Napoleon's First Battles simulates four early battles from the French Republican era, namely, "Montenotte", "Arcola", "The Pyramids" and "Marengo".

There are a basic and an advanced game. The wargame utilises the standard CRT (Assault Combat Result Table) which includes disruption. An elan rating is included to show the capability of a unit to close with the enemy in battle.

A separate artillery bombardment table is utilized to show the effects of artillery.

Contents:
1 standard rules booklet
400 double sided die counters
2 17"x22" maps
1 six sided die

Playing Time = 1 to 2 hours
Complexity = Low
Solitaire Suitability = High
7131.name: Napoleon's First Battles

7132.name: See-Queue
7132.description: This is a two - to four person tic-tac-toe-like game using a four level circular board. You try to complete a line of four in your color or an "orbit" in your color. Interesting "twist" on a rather basic game - interesting ability to add additional players - helps mitigate first player advantage.

7133.name: VCR Baseball
7133.description:
From the back of the box:

VCR Baseball is the exciting baseball strategy game that can turn an ordinary afternoon into a thrilling day at the ballpark. Become an actual player and see the outcome of your hits on TV as you watch the video tape containing footage of professional slugging action. Home runs, double plays, triples, fielding errors, pop-ups...it's all there for you to see and experience!

The basic game is quickly learned and fast playing. Each time you pitch or bat you choose a baseball strategy. Make your decision just as in real baseball -- depending on what kind of hit you want to get, how many outs there are, and if there are runners on the base. Then compare your choice with your opponent's and find out what happens. You could strike out, get a walk, or a hit. If it's a hit -- you watch the videotape to see the outcome!

And VCR Baseball is actually two strategy games in one. The advanced game adds more baseball depth. Your team players have their own batting and pitching abilities, so you can bring in a right-handed pinch hitter to try for a crucial hit off a lefty pitcher. Or relieve a tiring pitcher. Intentionally walk an excellent hitter, bunt or steal a base.

Features:
- 2 games in one!
- unlimited replayability
- for 2 players
- live footage of professional ball players in action
- fun for ages 12 to adult

Components:
- approx. 30-minute video tape
- colorful game board
- 6 playing pieces
- batting and pitching cards
- playing grids
- score pad
- player cards
- 3 dice

boardgamehonor.21368: 2012/Fall Parents' Choice Fun Stuff Award Winner

7134.description:
From the back of the box:

FIBBER! is the family fun board game with a great new twist -- when players announce what number they've rolled, how can you find out if they're telling the truth when you can't see their die? By challenging, that's how -- Just say "Are you a Fibber?" Off comes the top of their dice shaker and if they were fibbing -- whoops -- back they go; but if they were telling the truth -- then back you go!
7134.name: Fibber

7135.name: Tamagotchi: The Game
7135.description:
From the back of the box:

Everybody wants a TAMAGOTCHI toy, but not everyone has the devotion to raise one properly. Here's a perfect solution: The TAMAGOTCHI Game. Play this game with your friends, (with or without the TAMAGOTCHI toy.) Just keep your pet well-fed, happy, healthy, clean, well-trained and amused...before you know it you'll have a full-grown, fully nurtured pet!

Everything you need is here: 4 TAMAGOTCHI moving pieces, 72 nurturing cards, 4 growth meter and an exciting game board. The TAMAGOTCHI Game is a terrific way to enjoy some real interactive quality time with family, friends, and of course, your favorite pet!

7136.name: Escort: The Game of Guys and Gals
7136.description:
Object is for the player to move all three of his 'Gals" from their starting places on the board and into their "homes" on the opposite side of the board.

They're escorted home by the nine 'Guys' of each respective player.

Opposing 'Guys' can be captured by jumping.

'Guys' & 'Gals' can move in any direction, backward, forward, left, right or on diagonal.

'Gals' cannot jump and can only be used to block moves.

First player to succeed in getting all three of his 'Gals' into their 'homes' on the opposite side of the board wins the game.

7137.name: Screwball: The Mad, Mad, Mad Game
7137.description:
Every player or 'Boob' is in the "MADvertising business" on MADison Avenue. He drives his Jokeswagon along the path, collecting "clients" and slogans. Meanwhile he spends his Mad Money.

First Boob to lose all his Mad Money ends the game and he is the winner.... Unless... the richest of the remaining players holds in his hand the "Madly Rich" slogan - this player is then declared the winner.

Supposedly this game was at the center of a Mad Magazine lawsuit which Transogram lost. I haven't been able to find anything substantiating this.

30507.name: Overlord: D-Day and the Beachhead Battles

boardgamehonor.21401: 2002 Charles S. Roberts Best Wargame Graphics Nominee

7138.description:
New England Simulations revisits a familiar World War II venue -- the hedgerows of Normandy -- with some refreshing twists in The Killing Ground: Campaign for Normandy, July-August 1944". The game combines a mechanic usually reserved for smaller games -- a chit pull combat system -- with two gorgeous maps, 900 counters, and a 36-page rulebook that should have "Don't Panic!" inscribed on its cover (the designer was content to place the warning on the first page of rules instead).

As you read the rules, you get the feeling that the designer wants to bring back the best parts of the "good old days" of wargaming -- that newfound excitement and thrill you once had that gradually wore off as you slogged through the complexity of the latest SPI monster. The rulebook is written almost in prose, gently explaining each rule and including historical footnotes when appropriate. Though long, it is well-organized and easily cross-referenced.

The graphics are detailed but subtle, aiding play without distracting the player (in contrast with maps from games like The Gamers' "Thunder at the Crossroads", where the vibrant color can make you cross-eyed). Hues of gray and green predominate. A fair amount of information is packed on each counter. Player aids are plentiful.

The game itself focuses on post-invasion Normandy, where the Germans are trying to delay and attrite the Allies prior to their inevitable breakout. As much of the victory depends on the Allies' ability to maintain momentum throughout the campaign as it does capturing key victory point hexes -- any signs of trench warfare or, worse, seesaw battling over villages is severely penalized.

In yet another attempt to limit intelligence, the combat system includes a combat effectiveness 'chit pull' system that disguises actual unit combat strength up to the last moment. The system adds a level of uncertainty to the game that leads to unexpected combat results and tempers any tendency to attack without some forethought.

Although primarily designed for two players, the game can accommodate up to four given its size and attention to detail. The Killing Ground includes five scenarios, all historical.

Game Scale
Units: Primarily regimental with tank and other support units as battalions.
Time: Each game-turn is 1 day.
Map: 2.5km per hex.

A complete game of The Killing Ground will include the following:
1 rules booklet
1 Combat Manual
2 map sections (22” x 34” each)
3 different countersheets (900 counters printed front & back)
6 different charts (Combat Results Table, Allied Air Allocation Chart, US Army Support Points chart, British/Canadian Army Support Points chart, Game-Turn Record Track, Scenario Card).
2 six-sided dice
1 game box

Expanded by:

Overlord: D-Day and the Beachhead Battles
7138.name: The Killing Ground

7139.name: Campaigns of the Civil War: Vicksburg and Chancellorsville
7139.description:
Campaigns of the Civil War: Vicksburg and Chancellorsville is a wargame that simulates two critical events of the American Civil War through a game system with a map divided into strategic squares.

While this game is designed especially for solitaire play, it can accommodate a second player.

Individual counters represents divisions, brigades, leaders, ironclads, transports and a handful of companies and battalions deployed in probing operations.

A Combat Results Table (CRT) and a six-sided die is used to resolve combat.

7140.description:
This wargame simulates Operation Rheinubung where the German battleship Bismarck and the Prinz Eugen attempts a breakout into the Atlantic.

This is a two player operational simulation of that historical event. The game retains the tactical ship to ship elements of the encounter.

Each hex represents 75 nautical miles.

A Damage Point Table and a 10-sided die is used to resolve combat.

Dummy task forces and pre-plotted German movement is used to simulate the Fog of War.

Hypothetical scenarios and historical scenarios are provided. The hypothetical scenarios include a different order of battle. For example, the additions of the Scharnhorst and Gneisenau.
7140.name: Sink the Bismarck!

7141.description:
This standalone wargame utilises the game system as its predecessor 'Crossbows and Cannon' and "Royalists and Roundheads". The wargame features a command system intended to simulate the problems of command during the Renaissance where leaders are rated for command, initiative and combat.

The four battles are Pinkie 1547, Fornovo 1495, Cerignola 1503, Novara 1513.

Weapons in the game range from arquebuses, crossbows, cannon, pike and more. Units include stradiots,genitors, pikemen and more.

Advanced rules are included.
7141.name: Crossbows and Cannon II

7142.description:
This wargame is a brigade/regiment/battalion level simulation of Operation Zitadelle (Citadel) in 1943. The wargame is played in nine turns, each representing one day of real time. The 400 counters represent ground units of the above mentioned size and air units. Individual units include Tiger I battalions, Elephant battalions, Nashorn battalions infantry regiments, heavy rocket artillery regiments, dive-bomber units and more.

Combat is resolved through an Anti-Tank Fire Table and a Combat Results Table (CRT).

A split map of the northern and southern operations is included. In other words, there is no chance of encirclement by the Germans! In addition, the Orel sector is not included.
7142.name: Zitadelle: Duel for Kursk

7143.description:
This standalone wargame utilizes the game system as 3W's 'Royalists and Roundheads'. The wargame features a command system intended to simulate the problems of command during the Renaissance where leaders are rated for command, initiative and combat.

The four battles are Pavia 1525, Garigliano 1503, Ravenna 1512, and Bicocca 1522.

Weapons in the game range from arquebusses, crossbows, cannon, pike and more. Units include stradiots, genitors, pikemen and more.

A followup Crossbows and Cannon II is available.
7143.name: Crossbows and Cannon

7144.name: Master Herbalist
7144.description:
Object of the game is collect as many illness sets determined by the players.

In his/her turn, each player draws and Illness Card. He then places the card face up in front of him. The player then draws an Herb Card. He then has one chance to identify one illness that is listed on the Herb Dial under that Herb.

If the player is correct, he may retain the Herb Card.

It the Herb Card matches the illness of the card or cards he has, the player has the option of placing it under that illness card or saving it for other possible illness sets.

Winner is the player who first completes the predetermined number of Illness Sets.

7145.description: The animals are on the loose in the dice game Catz, Ratz and Batz! Roll the nine dice, then decide which to keep and which to reroll. Catz are good and multiply your score – unless you need them to cancel out the ratz, who will otherwise chew your points away. Batz, fluttering all over the place as they will, can be good or bad depending on what else you roll; they're good if you roll 3s, neutral if you roll 5s, and bad if you roll 7s. The first player to collect 250 points wins!
7145.name: Catz, Ratz and Batz

7146.name: Legal Decision
7146.description:
Legal Decision is a challenging game for Ages 14 and up. A game like you have never played before -- all the excitement and suspense of a courtroom trial! You can be the quick-witted defense attorney, State's tough prosecutor, jury foreman, or the judge himself! Witnesses testify, cross-examination may change testimony - jurors' sympathy can be swayed, new evidence may be introduced. The drama builds as the jury moves toward its verdict.

The designer is likely Rico Gatti who is listed as the copyright holder.

7147.name: The People's Court
7147.description: The People's Court game is based on the very popular television show where the litigants settle their disputes in Judge Wapner's courtroom. An exciting game where the players are plaintiffs trying to win cases by landing on 'Case Cards', such as Problem Pets, Neighborhood Feuds, Disservices and Shoddy Goods. And, just as on the TV show, Judge Wapner is the ultimate authority."

7148.name: Case Race
7148.description:
Welcome to West's Great American Case Race Game. The objective is to have some old-fashioned fun as you learn the advantages that determine success in computer-assisted legal research. But that's not all. It's a fast-moving game, and it will take some strategy and thinking to win. You will have to make a lot of on-the-spot decisions. The challenge makes the game all the more fun! The rules are straightforward and most of the rules for the game are printed on the board itself.
West Publishing Company was the parent company for the Westlaw computer-assisted research service, which this game was apparently designed to promote over the competing service, Lexis. The game includes Westlaw and Lexis cards. The Westlaw cards usually score points for the player due to efficient and easy to use services, while the Lexis cards typically cause the players to lose points because of purported 'difficulties' with West's competitor's service.

7149.name: Guilty Party
7149.description: You and your friends are the participants in the trial of David Defendant. The charge is MURDER TWO. After the attorneys and witnesses are finished with all the testimony all of you will become a jury to determine whether or not David was convicted or not. The testimony (facts) change from game to game so it's never the same.

7150.name: Attorney Power
7150.description: Ready to practice law? ATTORNEY POWER (1982) will give you a corner office and as many clients as you can handle, but you have to give oorrect advice to real legal problems. ATTORNEY POWER will give you the opportunity to conduct a bar investigation, neglect to file a lawsuit, give advice on changing a will, decide where to sue, and many more real life legal problems. The game has paralegals, fee gougers and client stealers, as well as 56 evidence and liability rulings based upon recent court decisions in both criminal and civil law.

7151.name: The Story of the U.S. Air Force
7151.description:
A Landmark Game based on volume 89 in the Landmark children's book series by Random House. For Ages 9 - 15

The game is a race starting from ground level to see who can be the first into orbit. The players start off with balloons and as they climb upwards various historical aircraft become available (including the Wright Flyer, Curtis Jenny, Spirit of St. Louis, P-51, F-104, and X-15). The higher the altitude reached, the more advanced the aircraft that may be acquired.

The game features colorful components with an interesting gimmick or two - for instance, the spinners are part of a box insert depicting an aircraft control panel, and the players use a miniature compass to try and get a correct reading on a radar screen box.

7152.name: The Boss
7152.description: "Have you got what it takes to make it to the Executive Suite, or is Office Boy as high as you'll rise? You'll find out when you play THE BOSS, the fun-filled game that realistically recreates the gotta-get-ahead world of today's big business! You've got to be shrewd enough to make the wildest deals you can dream up -- or break a deal that's holding you back! You can buy 'n lend stock, sell 'n trade Experience, promise future favors (and fail to deliver!) -- yes, you can wheel 'n deal any outrageous way you can get away with! It's fast-movin', fast-talkin', fast-dealin' fun -- all the way to the top!"

7153.name: PanzerForce
7153.description:
PanzerForce is a realistic game that shows the problems faced by tank commanders in World War II. But it is much more than just a game. The two different tanks that will collide in battle will respond and perform as they actually did. You, the tank commander, will make the decisions that lead to victory or defeat. This is tank combat, the way it really was, a game of deadly adventure."

A game of tactical tank-to-tank combat where two Tigers face off against four Shermans. The game uses 6 HO scale plastic tanks.

7154.name: Magnetic Poetry The Game for Kids
7154.description:
Be the first player to make it from the vegetable crisper to the freezer by win four poem-writing rounds.

One player is the judge, who spins a spinner to select the poem category (gross, sad, mad, pretty, silly, happy, gross) The remaining players write poems, based on a subject selected from their hand of subject cards, and using magnetic word tiles selected from the word board arrange them on their play board to form their poem befitting the category and subject. At the end of the three minute timer period, the judge selects the poem that is the best match of subject and category and declares the round winner, whose playing piece moves up one space towards the freezer on the score track. The judgeship passes to the left and play continues until one player wins their fourth poem round.

7155.name: Sue You!
7155.description: Sue You! was invented by a law student in the fall of 1991. He was intrigued -- and troubled -- by society's apparent fascination with lawsuits, and set out to create a game that would capture the essence of that fascination . . . The object of the game is to become the wealthiest player by successfully suing other players. The game ends when one of the players runs out of money. The player with the most money at that time is the winner."

7156.description:
It's Uno but with Hello Kitty on the cards.

WHAT MAKES IT DIFFERENT FROM TRADITIONAL UNO: 'Hello Kitty Love Me Not' wild card. Upon playing the 'Love Me Not' card the player names a color and discards one card in that color. Each player in turn must then also discard one card from their hand or draw from the draw pile. Those discarding must say "Love Me" and those drawing, "Love Me Not" else face the evil UNO penalty of drawing an additional card. Play then resumes as normal upon returning to the player intitiating the "love me(not)" session.
7156.name: UNO: Hello Kitty

7157.name: Play the Game
7157.description:
"Play the Game. The book you can play. Complete with counters and detailed rules."

"Welcome to the exciting world of Board Games! From the earliest known board game in the English language, A Journey Through Europe, invented in 1759, through Edwardian England's Golden Age of Games, to the mid-20th Century, you will travel 300 years of history and pleasure. There are great new experiences for aficionados, as well as intimate games for two and party games for many."

This book includes color photos of the boards from 46 vintage games. Rules are included, along with a sheet of pieces to cut out, so that all of the games may be played.

List of games included

7158.name: Great Board Games
7158.description:
Great Board Games. Over 40 games that you can play. 1895-1955. Complete with rules and counters."

Similar to the author's earlier "Play the Game" book, "Great Board Games" is a collection of 43 vintage games that you can play. There is a color photo of the board for each game, rules, and a few sheets of game pieces to be cut out.

7159.name: The Boardgame Book
7159.description:
The first edition (Knapp and Cavendish) was published in 1979. It came in a slipcase and included four 20"x26" double-sided sheets with extra-large game boards. The second edition (Exeter and Cavendish) was published in 1983 and does not have the slipcase or the extra sheets. Both editions have a loose sheet with cut-out pieces for the games in the book.

"Play a boardgame known to the Pharoahs of Egypt, called Senat. Exercise your skill on Go, a boardgame considered an important part of Samurai warriors' education in the seventeenth century. Learn how to play Mu Torere, a popular tribal boardgame from New Zealand, or Konane, the game Captain Cook found the natives playing in Hawaii. Introduce your children to your own childhood favorites, like Ludo, Checkers and Tic-Tac-Toe."

"The Boardgame Book is a beautiful compendium of the world's most entertaining and universally popular games. Every board in this fascinating and unique collection of over eighty games can be played on the page, because the book has been specially designed to open flat. For easy reference, instructions with diagrams explaining how to play are on the pages adjoining each board. All the pieces and other equipment needed for play are supplied on a separate cut-out sheet."

"Here is a unique collection of over eighty games from every part of the world and dating as far back as five thousand years. Some, though very popular in their countries of origin, are almost totally unknown abroad, and others are rarities only to be found in museums and private collections.

Many of the games reproduced in The Boardgame Book are from an especially fine collection built up by R.C. Bell over many years. All the games have been chosen as much for their interest and visual appeal as for their value as a pleasant and universal pastime. About one third of the boards reproduced in this book are completely new designs which have been specially commissioned, with all the details taking account of traditional models."

7160.name: Speed Dash
7160.description:
Speed Dash!! The Great Sailplane Race.

Strategic decisions you make in The Great Sailplane Race are much like those in real soaring competition. Whether you stay on the main course or fly Cloud Streets, Ridge Lift, or the Wave depends on the situation, how your competitors are doing, and how gutsy you are. A word of warning: Speed Dash brings out the tiger in a pilot!

7162.description: Part of the book and movie franchise of the same name, Rennschwein Rudi Rüssel is a simple racing game. Each player has a hand of cards numbered 1 to 10. Players simultaneously select and reveal a card. Whoever plays the highest number moves their racing pig, but only as far as the amount they beat the second highest card by. If two players play the same high card they swap positions on the race track! There are also special spaces that allow you to exchange a card from your hand for a card from a face-up deck of additional cards.
7162.name: Rennschwein Rudi Rüssel

7163.name: Omega Expedition
7163.description:
From the back of the box:

Embark on an epic adventure of truly biblical proportions when you descend deep into the foreboding recesses of the labyrinth in search of holy artifacts. Surmount obstacles and deadly pitfalls and survive encounters with fierce creatures and supernatural beings bent upon denying you access to the holy artifacts. Witness history unfolding before your eyes as you find, and recover, holy relics thought to be lost to the ages.

Game is designed for multiple modes of play:

Single Player Mode
Multi-Player Mode (2-3 Individual Players)
Team Mode (up to 4 players per team)

Ages 7 and up

Contents: Game Board; Explorer's Manual; 80 cards (Level I); 80 cards (Level II); 4 Holy Artifact cards; 6 Mission Directives cards

Bonus Game: Quest for the Holy Treasure
Bonus Game: Mystery of the Number Seven

7164.description:
Collectible card game with Warhammer 40,000 universe background. Interesting game mechanics (for a card game) that balance well tactical decisions and strategic elements.

The game represents battle between two armies, including Space Marines, Chaos, Eldar, Orks etc. for the conquest of an objective planet divided in 5 different strategic sectors.

A card represents: army units, actions to play during battle, and a die roll, all included in a single card depending on when and where it is played.

Every expansion has a new planet to conquer with 5 new sectors that change completely the approach with which a player can try to win, so players are encouraged to change deck and test different strategies to adapt in the new terrain of battle.
7164.name: Warhammer 40,000 Collectible Card Game

7165.name: Final Days: Miniatures Battle Game
7165.description:
From the publisher's website:

The Apocalypse is here!

The dead of the Earth have risen, and now they roam the land seeking living beings to feed upon. Powerful undead such as vampires and ghouls command legions of flesh-hungry zombies in chilling, inhuman war bands. Small pockets of resistance remain as humans wage a desperate battle for survival in a world where the waters have turned to blood and the sky is night everlasting.

Final Days is a complete boxed miniatures combat game where players command human freedom fighters or undead hordes in Earth's final battle! The combat system uses standard playing cards to determine the outcome of actions, and takes just minutes to learn. Play seamlessly with just two players or a group of eight or more! Everything you need to set up and play this fast-paced, hard-action game is included, and you can be up and running in no time. This boxed set includes Twenty-Five 25mm metal figures (8 different brand-new sculpts) to recreate your intense tabletop battles.

So grab your shotgun and bar the doors. The dead are coming and nobody is there to rescue you.

Final Days is a skirmish-level miniatures game that uses a standard deck of playing cards, with jokers, as its randomizer. Each figure has three attributes that determine how many cards it draws during combat, as well as determining how much damage the figure can take. As a figure takes damage, his combat effectiveness decreases. The game can be played with any number of players, and lasts on average 1 to 2 hours.

Box Contents

Rulebook
Scenario and Accessory Book
2 Double-sided B&W maps
Templates of burned-out cars, desks, dumpsters
2 Combat Trackers
Equipment counters
25 white metal miniatures:
Demon
Vampire
2 Ghouls
13 zombies
6 survivors
2 dogs

7167.description:
From the Avalanche Press website:
German mountain troops fought on every front except North Africa, compiling an impressive war record (and a few war crimes as well). These elite “mountaineers of the plains” saw action in all sorts of terrain and in all weather.

Edelweiss is a 64-page book supplement for the Panzer Grenadier series, based on the battles fought by German regular army and Waffen SS mountain troops. It is not a complete game: playing pieces and maps are drawn from the following Panzer Grenadier games and supplements: Elsenborn Ridge, 1940 - The Fall of France, Arctic Front, Road to Berlin, Battle of the Bulge, Sinister Forces, Eastern Front, Afrika Korps and Desert Rats. There are 41 (forty-one!) scenarios, each based on an actual battle or situation, plus historical background on the German mountain divisions and their exploits.

Edelweiss includes 161 laser-cut and mounted playing pieces: 157 of them the standard 2/3-inch square pieces of the Panzer Grenadier series, and four of them double-sized monsters. Two are Soviet river monitors, and there are two versions of the giant motorized mortar "Karl."
7167.name: Panzer Grenadier: Edelweiss

37383.name: Panzer Grenadier: 1940 – The Fall of France
